awd_titl_txt: SUSCHEM:  Exploring Specific Heating in Microwave-assisted Synthesis of Hierarchical Hybrid Nanomaterials for Future Sustainable Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Batteries are ubiquitous electrical energy storage devices in our life to support anything from portable electronics to electrical grids. A key component that determines the cost and performance of batteries is the electrode materials. This project, funded by the Solid State Materials and Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research at NSF, seeks to develop new methods to prepare novel electrode materials that can be used for two types of emerging batteries, i.e. sodium ion batteries and magnesium ion batteries. These new battery-types use earth-abundant sodium and magnesium ions in electrochemical reactions and hence have the potential to significantly lower the cost of energy storage compared to current state-of-the-art Li-ion batteries, making them attractive for large-scale electrical energy storage. However, currently used single-phase electrode materials in these batteries exhibit poor stability and a short lifetime due to hosting the much larger sodium ions and higher-charged magnesium ions. Therefore this project targets hybrid materials which consist of active electrode materials deposited on stable three-dimensional nanostructured carbon scaffolds. The research approach makes use of the relatively strong microwave absorption by the nanocarbon materials to accelerate the synthesis process and create strong hybrid materials that otherwise may be unstable in separated phases. In addition to creating a better understanding of the fundamental properties of hybrid solid state materials and potentially improving the performance of electrical energy storage devices, this project provides cross-disciplinary training to students from diverse backgrounds including underrepresented groups. All three aspects are critical for maintaining our nation's leading role in the strategically important fields of energy conversion and storage.


PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This project, funded by the Solid State Materials and Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research at NSF, targets the development of well-controlled three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical hybrid electrode materials for two types of emerging batteries, i.e. sodium ion batteries and magnesium ion batteries, by depositing desired active electrode materials (metal oxides and chalcogenides) on nanostructured carbon templates using an innovative microwave-assisted synthesis method. Rapid heating, based on the specific microwave absorption of the nanocarbon templates, induces rapid nucleation and growth of metastable phases which combine into stable hybrid electrode materials that cannot be readily synthesized with conventional methods. Different types of nanocarbons, including dispersed nanoflakes of reduced graphene oxides (rGOs), stacked 3D films of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) or electrospun carbon nanofibers (CNFs), and arrays of vertically aligned carbon nanofibers (VACNFs), are investigated as highly conductive and mechanically robust templates to control the morphology, composition and phases of the deposited active electrode materials. This provides techniques for synthesizing delicate 3D hierarchical core-shell hybrid materials containing metastable materials such as hydrated metal oxides (V2O5·nH2O bilayers) and metal chalcogenides (VS4 chains) which have more opened structures to facilitate reversible storage of large Na+ ions and divalent Mg2+ ions. Such hybrid hierarchical materials may break the intrinsic limits of single-phase electrode materials by enhancing the electrical conductivity and reducing the ion diffusion path length in the solid materials while significantly improving the electrode's stability. The capability of fast heating by microwave irradiation shortens the materials synthesis processes and greatly accelerates materials discovery and optimization. This project also provides cross-disciplinary training to both graduate and undergraduate students in nanomaterials synthesis/characterization, electrochemistry and electrical energy storage technologies. Outreach activities are aimed at interesting K-12 students (particularly girls) in Kansas in STEM education, and engaging an undergraduate student from Xavier University (underrepresented minority) in summer research and further career development each year.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to develop well-controlled hybrid electrode materials for emerging batteries by depositing active materials on nanostructured carbon templates using innovative microwave-assisted synthesis methods. The hypothesis is that the rapid heating based on the specific microwave absorption by the nanocarbon templates may induce rapid nucleation and growth of metastable phases as the hybrid electrode materials that are not readily synthesized by conventional methods.

 

In the initial period, three types of nanocarbons, including dispersed nanoflakes of graphene oxides (GOs), stacked films of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and electrospun carbon nanofibers (CNFs), and arrays of vertically aligned carbon nanofibers (VACNFs), have been explored as highly conductive and mechanically robust templates to control the morphology, composition and phase of the deposited active electrode materials. In later periods, the foci were placed on GO as the starting template materials due to its high dispersibility in solution, high microwave absorptivity and easy conversion into highly conductive reduced graphene oxide (rGO) during the microwave process and following thermal annealing. Four types of active electrical storage materials have been investigated, including hydrated vanadium pentoxide (V2O5?nH2O), chain-liked VS4 nanocrystals, two-dimensional (2D) MoS2 nanopatches, and microwave-exfoliated V2O5 nanoribbons (NRs). The latter two were found to be very interesting cathode materials for aqueous Zinc-ion batteries (AZIBs). AZIB is an emerging sustainable and safer technology for large-scale electrical energy storage but is limited by lack of electrode materials for reversible insertion/extraction of Zn2+ ions due to their larger disruption to the host structure than Li+ ions.

 

By microwave specific heating to the GO nanosheets, the Mo precursor is quickly deposited on the GO surface to form a disordered chain-structured MoS3 intermediate containing a high portion of S22- among S2-. After thermal annealing in 3% H2 and 97% Ar at 250, 325 and 600 ?C, respectively, the MoS3 is converted into 2D layered MoS2 nanopatches. The MoS2/rGO structure can be tuned from highly crystalline MoS2 nanopatches (annealed at 600 ?C) to highly defective S-rich MoS2 (at 250 ?C). All three MoS2/rGO hybrids and the MoS3/rGO intermediate show a high Li-ion intercalation capacity in the initial cycles (over 519 mAh/gMoSx, ~3.1 Li+ ions per MoS2) while the effect of defects is insignificant. In contrast, the Zn-ion storage properties strongly depend on the defects. The highly defective MoS2/rGO hybrid (annealed at 250 ?C) shows the highest initial Zn-ion storage capacity (~300 mAh/gMoSx) and nearly 100% coulombic efficiency, which are dominated by pseudocapacitive surface reactions at the edges or defects in the MoS2 nanopatches. The fast capacity fading in the initial cycles can be mitigated by applying higher charge/discharge currents or extended cycles. It validates that defect engineering is critical for improving Zn-ion storage in MoSx/rGO hybrid materials.

 

In studying V2O5 materials, we discovered a microwave-assisted exfoliation process for high-yield V2O5 NRs from orthorhombic α-V2O5 crystals. This method is extended to prepare Zinc-ion cathode materials using divalent M2+ (Zn2+ and Mn2+) ions to bridge the negatively charged V2O5 nanoribbons and GO nanosheets in a coprecipitation process. The divalent metal ions M2+ (Zn2+ and Mn2+) effectively neutralize the negative charges on the surface of V2O5 NRs and GO nanosheets to form a strongly bound assembly. After thermal annealing in nitrogen atmosphere, GO is converted into rGO with a high electrical conductivity while the layers in V2O5 NRs are expanded by M2+ intercalation. When only Zn2+ ions are used during coprecipitation, the produced Zn-V2O5 NR/rGO hybrid shows a very high reversible specific capacity of ~386 mAh/g at 0.50 A/g but a poor stability. This is improved by mixing Mn2+ with Zn2+ ions during coprecipitation. The (Mn+Zn)-V2O5 NR/rGO hybrid shows a slightly lower specific capacity of ~289 mAh/g at 0.5 A/g but a substantially improved long-cycling stability and better rate-performance due to the stronger binding of Mn2+ ions with the V2O5 host, which serve as stable pillars to expand the V2O5 layers.

 

This project provided interdisciplinary training to 5 graduate students (2 completed Ph.D., 1 completed MS, and 2 still in the Ph.D. program). The nanomaterials fabrication, characterization and electrochemical evaluation developed in this project are transformative to broad fields and led to two new grants from DOE and NSF. The results have been disseminated in 10 journal papers, 1 book chapter, 1 submitted manuscript, and 14 conference presentations. Strong bilateral collaboration with a minority-serving institution (Xavier University at Louisiana - XULA) has been established, involving visit of the faculty collaborator and summer internship of an undergraduate student, and recruiting a graduate student from XULA. One postdoc and one Ph.D. student from the PI's group were hired to XULA as postdocs. Over 4 hands-on workshops using fuel cell and solar cell demo kits have been offered to K-12 students to stimulate their interests in STEM.

 


Last Modified: 08/06/2022
Modified by: Jun Li
